facts.text: Dhananjoy Mullick, adoptive father of Mrityunjoy, died on 28th August 1907, leaving widow Nitto Sundari and adopted son Mrityunjoy (minor).
On 11th February 1910, Nitto Sundari obtained letters of administration to the estate of Dhananjoy limited during minority of Mrityunjoy.
On 13th June 1920, Nitto Sundari purchased premises No. 14, Syakrapara Lane out of monies belonging to estate of Dhananjoy.

On 10th October 1934, Nitto Sundari conveyed premises No. 14, Syakrapara Lane to Mrityunjoy (who had attained majority); same day, Nitto Sundari and Mrityunjoy executed indenture dedicating properties in Schedules A and B (including premises No. 14) to deity Nitto Gopal Jew.

Indenture provided: Nitto Sundari shebait for life; then Mrityunjoy; then his wife Sm. Kiranbala Dassi; then heirs of Mrityunjoy as shebait or shebaits. Proviso: if Mrityunjoy dies without issue or without authority to wife surviving to adopt, he may appoint shebait after wife's death; if no issue, shebaitship after wife devolves on his heirs under Hindu Law. Remuneration: 25% net income to shebait(s).
Nitto Sundari died in 1938; Mrityunjoy became shebait.
Kiranbala, first wife of Mrityunjoy, died on 14th January 1942, leaving infant son Debabrata (defendant).
Soon after Kiranbala's death, Mrityunjoy married plaintiff Angurbala as second wife.

Plaintiff Angurbala filed suit on 29th August 1947 in Original Side Calcutta High Court (Suit No. 2481 of 1947) for declaration of sole shebait or jointly with defendant under indenture or Hindu Women's Rights to Property Act, and right of residence in premises No. 14.
No evidence adduced; case argued on construction of indenture and Hindu Women's Rights to Property Act 1937 (as amended 1938).

Trial Judge (single Judge Original Side Calcutta HC) on 9th February 1949: plaintiff not sole or joint shebait; Act inapplicable to shebaitship; not natural guardian to act for minor defendant; but entitled to residence. Other prayers dismissed.
Appeal to Division Bench Calcutta HC (Harries CJ, Sinha J) on 19th May 1950 affirmed trial judgment, relying on Umayal Achi v. Lakshmi Achi (1945 FCR 1); appeal only pressed on joint shebaitship.
Plaintiff obtained certificate under Article 133(1)(c) Constitution; appeal to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether plaintiff entitled to shebaitship solely or jointly with defendant under indenture or as heir under Hindu Women's Rights to Property Act 1937.
Whether Hindu Women's Rights to Property Act applies to devolution of shebaitship.
Construction of indenture: meaning of 'heirs of Mrityunjoy'; effect of proviso; whether heirs as words of gift or limitation to issue.

petitioner_arguments.text: Under indenture, after Kiranbala (predeceased Mrityunjoy), shebaitship to heirs of Mrityunjoy; heirs determined by law at succession (post-1937 Act), widow shares equally with son as property.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Hindu Women's Rights to Property Act s.3; shebaitship as property

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if 'property' in Act excludes shebaitship expressly, succession to shebaitship follows ordinary Hindu law inheritance rules, amended by Act.
Indenture gives wife (Kiranbala descriptive) priority over other heirs.

respondent_arguments.text: Hindu Women's Rights to Property Act does not apply to shebaitship (special anomalous property); not intended per preamble, ss.3(3),5; distinguishes from secular property.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Hindu Women's Rights to Property Act ss.3,5; Umayal Achi v. Lakshmi Achi 1945 FCR 1

respondent_arguments.text: Indenture intends issue of Mrityunjoy prefer over other heirs; 'heirs' in main clause means issue per proviso; no other heir till failure of issue.
'Heirs of Mrityunjoy' words of direct gift, fixed at grant time (1934, pre-Act); not words of limitation/devotion.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Construction of indenture; Umayal Achi v. Lakshmi Achi

court_reasoning.text: Shebaitship is property blending office/duties with beneficial interest (25% income); heritable per Hindu law unless founder directs otherwise.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proprietary element in shebaitship admitted in Hindu law.

court_reasoning.text: Hindu Women's Rights to Property Act s.3(1) 'any property' includes shebaitship; preamble, s.3(3), s.5 do not limit to secular/non-testamentary property.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act amends general succession law applicable to shebaitship.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes Umayal Achi: trusts there lacked beneficial interest; shebaitship has it; followed Madras HC in archakatvam case.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act applies where beneficial interest exists.

court_reasoning.text: Indenture: 'heirs' means all heirs under law at succession time; proviso exception for appointment if no issue/no adoption authority; not words of gift; issue (defendant) lives, but widow also heir under Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proviso qualifies main clause; contingency not arisen.

court_reasoning.text: Plaintiff not sole shebait (not pressed); entitled jointly as co-heir.

holdings.text: Hindu Women's Rights to Property Act 1937 applies to succession to shebaitship as heritable property.
Under indenture, after Mrityunjoy, shebaitship devolves on his heirs under Hindu law (as amended); plaintiff widow entitled to joint shebaitship with son defendant.
'Heirs' in indenture words of limitation/devotion, not gift; governed by law at death.

precedents_cited.relevance: Shebait not trustee like English law; manager with beneficial interest.

precedents_cited.case_name: Manohar Mukherji v. Bhupendra Nath Mukherji
precedents_cited.relevance: Proprietary character of shebaitship; approved by PC.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ganesh Chunder Dhur v. Lal Behary

precedents_cited.relevance: Anomaly of shebaitship as property accepted in Hindu law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gossamee Sree Greedharreejee v. Rumanlolljee Gossamee
precedents_cited.relevance: Shebaitship vests in heirs of founder unless otherwise disposed.
Act inapplicable to pure trusteeships without beneficial interest; not shebaitship.
Widow succeeding to shebaitship holds Hindu woman's estate; reverts to last male's heirs.
Act applies to hereditary religious office (archakatvam) with beneficial interest; distinguishes Umayal Achi.

statutes_cited.name: Hindu Women's Rights to Property Act, 1937 (Act XVIII of 1937, amended by Act XI of 1938)
statutes_cited.relevance: Amends succession: widow entitled to son's share in intestate property including shebaitship; applies where intestate (no effective will); interest as Hindu woman's estate.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgments of courts below set aside except declaration of plaintiff's right of residence; declared plaintiff entitled to joint shebaitship with defendant in respect of debuttar created by indenture of 10th October 1934.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration of joint shebaitship with defendant; confirmation of right of residence in premises No. 14, Syakrapara Lane.
outcome.costs: Taxed costs of both parties in all courts to be paid out of debuttar estate.

key_quotes.text: It is the presence of this personal or beneficial interest in the endowed property which invests shebaitship with the character of proprietary rights and attaches to it the legal incidents of property.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines shebaitship as property subject to Hindu succession laws.

key_quotes.text: Our conclusion, therefore, is that there is nothing in any of the provisions of the Hindu Womens Rights Property Act which excludes from the scope of operation of the Act succession to shebaitship is a recognized form of property in Hindu Law.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The result, therefore, is that, in our opinion, the appeal succeeds.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Final determination allowing appeal for joint shebaitship.
